column5: A 58-year-old male presents to the emergency department with intermittent chest discomfort at rest for the past week. The pain is described as a pressure-like sensation in the substernal region, lasting 15-20 minutes per episode. He has a medical history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a 20-pack-year smoking history, quitting 5 years ago. Initial evaluation reveals a blood pressure of 165/95 mmHg, heart rate of 88 bpm, and normal oxygen saturation. An ECG demonstrates nonspecific ST-segment depression in the lateral leads, and the initial high-sensitivity troponin I is within normal limits.
column6: Admit for acute coronary syndrome rule-out with serial troponins and cardiology consultation
column7: A grade III/VI crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur is appreciated at the right upper sternal border radiating to the carotid arteries

column5: A 62-year-old man presents with 45 minutes of substernal pressure radiating to the left arm, accompanied by diaphoresis and nausea. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia and smokes one pack per day. Vitals: BP 168/92 mmHg, HR 98 bpm, O2 sat 97% on room air; lungs are clear and there is no audible murmur on initial exam. ECG shows 1-2 mm horizontal ST depressions in V4-V6 with T-wave inversions, and high-sensitivity troponin is mildly elevated.
column6: NSTEMI; start ACS protocol (aspirin, P2Y12 inhibitor, anticoagulation, beta-blocker) and plan early coronary angiography.
column7: There is a 25 mmHg systolic blood pressure difference between arms and an early decrescendo diastolic murmur at the left sternal border; a portable chest radiograph shows a widened mediastinum.

column5: A 67-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 4-hour history of central chest pressure radiating to her jaw, associated with mild dyspnea and diaphoresis. She has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. On examination, her blood pressure is 150/92 mmHg and heart sounds are normal, with no murmurs or added sounds. An initial ECG shows non-specific ST-segment changes.
column6: Acute coronary syndrome; order cardiac enzymes and serial ECGs.
column7: She reports having started a new medication for her rheumatoid arthritis two weeks ago and notes a recent episode of severe upper respiratory tract infection.

column5: A 68-year-old male with a 35-pack-year smoking history presents with progressive dyspnea on exertion over the past 6 months, now awakening at night gasping for breath and requiring three pillows to sleep. Physical examination reveals bilateral basal crackles, 2+ pitting edema to the mid-shin, and an elevated jugular venous pressure at 8 cm H2O. He denies any known prior cardiac history or previous myocardial infarction.
column6: Suspect ischemic cardiomyopathy; order transthoracic echocardiogram
column7: The patient mentions that his fingertips turn white then blue when exposed to cold, and he has recently been diagnosed with esophageal dysmotility requiring PPI therapy.

column5: A 28-year-old female graduate student presents to the emergency department with sharp, left-sided chest pain that worsens with deep inspiration and lying supine. The pain began 3 days ago and is associated with mild dyspnea. She reports a viral upper respiratory infection 2 weeks prior. Physical examination reveals a temperature of 38.2°C, a prominent triphasic pericardial friction rub, and no evidence of cardiac tamponade. ECG demonstrates diffuse concave ST-segment elevation and PR depression in leads I, II, aVF, and V2-V6.
column6: Prescribe high-dose NSAIDs and colchicine for acute viral pericarditis
column7: She is currently 16 weeks pregnant.

column5: Error
column6: Error
column7: Error

column5: A 72-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with complaints of chest discomfort, mild shortness of breath, and feeling lightheaded for the past few hours. Her past medical history is significant for controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia; she is a non-smoker. On examination, her blood pressure is 132/78 mmHg, heart rate is 62 bpm, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. There are no murmurs or jugular venous distension, but she appears mildly diaphoretic. Her ECG reveals new-onset atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response.
column6: Order cardiac enzymes and start rate control therapy
column7: Lab results show a mild elevation in troponin and significant hypokalemia on the basic metabolic panel

column5: A 58-year-old male presents with progressive exertional dyspnea and bilateral lower extremity edema over the past 6 months. He reports occasional palpitations and intermittent chest tightness. Physical examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure, bilateral pitting edema to the mid-shin, and a holosystolic murmur at the apex radiating to the axilla. Laboratory studies show BNP of 680 pg/mL with otherwise normal comprehensive metabolic panel. He has no family history of cardiac disease.
column6: Dilated cardiomyopathy with functional mitral regurgitation
column7: Medical record review reveals he received mantle field radiation therapy for Hodgkin lymphoma 35 years ago

column5: A 62-year-old man with long-standing uncontrolled hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with abrupt-onset severe substernal chest pain while lifting a heavy object, associated with diaphoresis and nausea. The pain radiates to his left arm and jaw and has persisted for 40 minutes; he denies prior similar episodes. Vital signs: BP 186/98 mm Hg, HR 102 bpm, RR 18/min, O2 sat 97% on room air; exam reveals no murmurs and clear lungs. ECG shows 1–2 mm horizontal ST depressions in leads V4–V6, and the first high-sensitivity troponin is mildly elevated.
column6: Treat as NSTEMI: start aspirin and heparin, initiate beta-blocker, obtain serial troponins, and arrange early coronary angiography.
column7: On re-examination, there is a 25 mm Hg systolic blood pressure difference between arms with a diminished right radial pulse, a new early diastolic decrescendo murmur at the left sternal border, and the patient describes the pain as initially tearing to the interscapular back.

column5: A 62-year-old man with long-standing hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and stage 3 chronic kidney disease presents with 90 minutes of central chest pressure radiating to the left arm, with diaphoresis and nausea. Vitals: BP 184/102 mmHg, HR 98 bpm, SpO2 97% on room air. Cardiac exam initially reveals no murmurs and symmetric peripheral pulses. ECG shows 1–2 mm horizontal ST depressions in V4–V6; high-sensitivity troponin I is 52 ng/L (upper reference limit 14).
column6: NSTEMI; start aspirin and a P2Y12 inhibitor, initiate IV anticoagulation, arrange early invasive coronary angiography.
column7: Thirty minutes later, he develops sudden severe tearing pain radiating to the interscapular region with brief right arm weakness. Blood pressure is 170/88 mmHg in the left arm and 135/80 mmHg in the right, and a new early diastolic murmur is audible at the right upper sternal border.

column5: A 68-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain radiating to her back that began 2 hours ago. She describes the pain as tearing and severe, rating it 9/10. Her blood pressure is 178/95 mmHg in the right arm and 142/88 mmHg in the left arm. She has a history of poorly controlled hypertension for 15 years and is a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history. Physical examination reveals a new early diastolic murmur at the left sternal border.
column6: Acute aortic dissection - order urgent CT angiography of chest
column7: Troponin I returns significantly elevated at 8.2 ng/mL with ST-segment elevations in leads II, III, and aVF on repeat ECG

column5: A 68-year-old woman presents with chest pain radiating to her left arm that started while she was gardening and lasted about 20 minutes before resolving with rest. She reports increasing shortness of breath over the past few months and decreased exercise tolerance. Her past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia, and she is a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history. On examination, her blood pressure is 148/92 mmHg, heart rate is 88 bpm, and she has no murmurs or added heart sounds.
column6: Suspect stable angina; order a stress test and ECG.
column7: On further questioning, she describes occasional episodes of palpitations and lightheadedness over the past few weeks, and her home blood pressure diary reveals several recent readings in the low 90s/60s mmHg range.

column5: A 58-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute onset chest pain and dyspnea. He reports the pain started 6 hours ago while at rest, is pressure-like, and radiates to his left arm. Vital signs show HR 105, BP 140/90, O2 sat 95% on room air. ECG reveals diffuse ST-segment elevation and PR depression. Troponin I is markedly elevated at 15.2 ng/mL. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medications.
column6: Acute pericarditis with myocardial involvement; initiate NSAIDs and colchicine
column7: He received his second dose of mRNA COVID-19 vaccine 4 days prior to symptom onset.

column5: Error
column6: Error
column7: Error

column5: A 32-year-old woman, five days after an uncomplicated vaginal delivery, arrives at the emergency department with rapidly worsening shortness of breath, palpitations, and difficulty lying flat. She reports mild pleuritic discomfort but denies fevers or leg swelling. Past history is notable only for iron-deficiency anemia during pregnancy; she received low-dose prophylactic enoxaparin for two days postpartum and then discontinued it. Vital signs reveal HR 118 bpm, BP 102/68 mm Hg, RR 24/min, and SpO₂ 92 % on room air. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention to the angle of the mandible, bibasilar crackles, and a new S₃ gallop.
column6: Peripartum cardiomyopathy—order transthoracic echocardiogram and begin IV diuretics
column7: Computed-tomography pulmonary angiography obtained for worsening hypoxia demonstrates multiple bilateral segmental filling defects within the pulmonary arteries.

column5: A 68-year-old African American woman presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset chest pain radiating to her left arm and shortness of breath. She has a history of poorly controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes, but no prior cardiac events. On physical exam, her blood pressure is 165/98 mmHg, heart rate is 102 bpm, and she appears diaphoretic. An ECG shows mild ST-segment depressions in the lateral leads. Initial labs reveal elevated troponin I just above the normal threshold.
column6: Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), initiate antiplatelet therapy and plan for coronary angiography.
column7: During review of her medication history, you discover she has been on long-term prednisone for recently diagnosed polymyalgia rheumatica and her creatinine today is significantly higher than her baseline.

column5: A 67-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain radiating to her back that started 3 hours ago. She describes it as tearing in nature, rating it 9/10 in severity. Her blood pressure is 168/95 mmHg in the right arm and 132/78 mmHg in the left arm. She has a history of poorly controlled hypertension for 15 years and is a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history. On examination, she appears distraught and diaphoretic with diminished femoral pulses bilaterally.
column6: Acute aortic dissection - order emergent CT angiography of chest and abdomen
column7: Transthoracic echocardiogram shows severe aortic regurgitation with a dilated aortic root measuring 5.2 cm and a visible intimal flap in the ascending aorta

column5: Error
column6: Error
column7: Error

column5: A 67-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain radiating to her left arm and jaw that began 3 hours ago. She has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a 30 pack-year smoking history. Her initial ECG shows ST-segment elevations in leads II, III, and aVF. Troponin I is elevated at 8.2 ng/mL. Blood pressure is 142/88 mmHg, heart rate is 92 bpm, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air.
column6: Acute inferior wall ST-elevation myocardial infarction requiring emergent cardiac catheterization
column7: The patient reports she took sildenafil approximately 6 hours ago for pulmonary symptoms and her blood pressure suddenly drops to 82/50 mmHg after administration of sublingual nitroglycerin

column5: A 60-year-old male with a 35-pack-year smoking history and poorly controlled hypertension presents to the emergency department with sudden, squeezing substernal chest pain that began one hour ago while shoveling snow. The pain radiates to his jaw, is rated 8/10, and is accompanied by diaphoresis and mild shortness of breath. Vital signs on arrival are BP 190/100 mm Hg (right arm), HR 92 bpm, RR 20, SpO₂ 97% on room air, and afebrile. Cardiovascular exam reveals no murmurs or rubs; lungs are clear. A 12-lead ECG shows 1 mm horizontal ST depressions in leads V4–V6, and the initial high-sensitivity troponin is pending.
column6: Possible NSTEMI; start dual antiplatelet therapy and IV heparin, arrange cardiology consult and admission.
column7: A repeat set of vitals taken 15 minutes later shows a systolic blood pressure of 190 mm Hg in the right arm and 150 mm Hg in the left arm, with a markedly weaker left radial pulse.
